div.head: To my old Faithfull Seruant: and (by his continu'd Vertue) my louing Friend: the Author of this Work, M. RICH. BROM • .
div.l: I Had you for a Seruant, once, Dick Brome;
And you perform'd a Seruants faithfull parts:
Now, you are got into a nearer roome,
Of Fellowship, professing my old Arts.
And you doe doe them well, with good applause,
Which you haue iustly gained from the Stage,
By obseruation of those Comick Lawes
Which I, your Master, first did teach the Age.
You learn'd it well; and for it, seru'd your time
A Prentise-ship: which few doe now a dayes.
Now each Court-Hobby-horse will wince in rime;
Both learned, and vnlearned, all write Playes.
It was not so of old▪ Men tooke vp trades
That knew the Crafts they had bin bred in, right:
An honest Bilbo-Smith Would make good blades,
And the Physician teach men spue, or shite;
The Cobler kept him to his nall; but, now
Hee'll be a Pilot, scarce can guide a Plough.
